chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should set a clear national guarantee that everyone can get essential care—primary, preventive, mental health, and emergency services—without financial ruin, while allowing people to buy additional private coverage and keep choice of providers. It should focus on rules and incentives that lower costs and improve outcomes, such as transparent pricing, standardized billing, stronger competition where it works, and negotiated rates where markets fail. Local systems and private organizations can deliver care in different ways as long as they meet access and quality standards, with special attention to rural, underserved, and high-need communities.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee that everyone has access to affordable, timely essential healthcare—especially primary, preventive, mental-health, and emergency care—and protection from catastrophic medical bills so no family is pushed into medical debt. It should set clear quality and transparency standards, reduce administrative waste, and use smart cost controls to protect taxpayers while improving outcomes. Within that baseline, policy should preserve meaningful choice by partnering with private and nonprofit providers and allowing supplemental private options, while supporting underserved rural and vulnerable communities.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure every person has access to a clear, affordable baseline of essential healthcare—primary, preventive, mental health, and emergency care—so no family is pushed into medical bankruptcy. It should set transparent price and quality standards, reduce administrative waste, and fund targeted help for seniors, children, low-income workers, and rural communities. At the same time, policy should preserve choice by allowing private plans and providers to compete and innovate above the basic guarantee, with strong accountability to protect taxpayers and patients.
